Ponchak squeaks by Hertsgaard
Junior Steve Ponchak was
elected student Council President
last week in a close contest with
Mark Hertsgaard.
The final tally of a special
run-off election for SC President
totaled Ponchak with 397 votes
to Hertsgaard's 369. In the initial
run-off election Ponchak received
four more votes than Hertsgaard,
but he came up with less than the
necessary "majority plus one"
because of three write-in votes.
What are your observations on
the functioning of this year's
Student Council? What, if
anything, went wrong, and what
proposals do you have for next
year?
This year's Council had many
things it wanted to accomplish,
but because of adverse time
factors and a lack of insight on
the part of some of the members,
they were not accomplished.
Intersession is one example
when the time factor was so
much against us that to
accomplish anything proved
difficult.
Interaction
I feel that people were a little
uncomfortable in the personal
interaction they had with the
leadership this year.
This summer I will be around
to deal with a number of issues
affecting students, including the
recently conceived merit
scholarship concept. I will fight

this proposal. I don't favor
throwing away thousands of
dollars on rich students.
The only type of merit
scholarships which I favor are
those which also take financial
need into consideration.
Could you comment on the
results of the elections and cite
those factors which you feel were
important in your winning?
I would first like to ask those
people that backed Mark
[Hertsgaard] in the election to
lend me their support in the
coming year.
I feel that I won the election
because of my past
accomplishments which gave me
necessary contacts. I was
sophomore class treasurer and
during the year I ran an
unsuccessful dance which, if
nothing else, showed me how not
to do things.
I was active in the class booth
in the Spring Fair and assisted in
the class Pancake breakfast and
numerous other functions during
my sophomore year. I . am a
junior class representative this
year.
You were not active in student
affairs during your freshman
year. What caused you to get
involved the following year?
I like the people in our class a
lot. I realized that this place was
small enough so that you could
get something done, a handful of

people can have impact.
In the past year there has
existed some controversy
centering around the relationship
between the News-Letter and the
Student Council. Could you
comment on this situation?
The big gripe on the Student
Council this year has been that
the coverage of things we did was
insufficient.
I feel that people on the
Council have been pushing too
hard from the start to get things
in the News-Letter. But, still, 1
feel that basically the
News-Letter is to blame for all
this. The News-Letter is today
more literary than informative.
What innovations, if any, do
you propose in the relation
Hopkins has with the
surrounding Baltimore
community?
I am in favor of increasing any
type of solicitation by private
groups on campus. I Want outside
groups to have access to Hopkins.
I want to say that the only
reason we have had no
cooperation with Sam's Belly [a
Waverley-based food co-op] has
been because of certain technical
aspects of the operation. The
modes are , dissimilar. Today
we're having a meeting with
Sam's Belly and I'm optimistic
that the meeting will bring out
some things that might lead to
greater cooperation.

Lewis Thomas to be
Graduation speaker
President Steven Muller
disclosed last week that this
year's commencement speaker
will be Lewis Thomas, president
of the Memorial Sloan-Kettering
Cancer Center.
• Thomas is highly esteemed for
his extraordinary perspective
regarding the place of science in
society. A series of essays, begun
in 1971 and written in layman's
language was published in the
New England Journal of
Medicine. Twenty-nine of these
were collected to form Lives of A
Cell: Notes of a Biology Watcher
which received a 1975 National
Book Award in the Arts and
Letters Category.
As a scientist, Thomas has

served as chairman of the
National Academy of Sciences
Committee charged with
evaluating the five-year campaign
against cancer, authorized by the
National Cancer Act. Thomas is
well known for his emphasis on
intuition and imagination in
scientific research, as opposed to
an engineering approach which
he feels yields few ideas. "What
must be planned for is totally
unforeseeable."
He has served on the medical
faculties of Hopkins. Yale, and
NYU medical schools and is a
member of the .National
Academy of Science and the
American Academy of Arts and
Sciences.

Entwisle and Harvey awarded Guggenheim grants
By JEFF PETERSOHN
Professors David Harvey,
Geography and Environmental
Engineering and Doris Entwisle,
Social Relations and Electrical
Engineering, have been named
recipients of this year's John
Simon Guggenheim Memorial
Fellowships. They are among the
300 scientists, scholars and artists
selected by the Guggenheim
Foundation to share grants
totaling $4,192,000 in its 52nd
annual competition.
The fellows were selected from
2953 applicants on the basis of
"demonstrated accomplishment
in the past and strong promise
for the future." The one-year
fellowships provide, in
conjunction with additional
monies from the University,
funding to enable sabbaticals in
favor of doing research, writing a
book or another equally

scholarly pursuit.
Harvey, a researcher in urban
geography, intends to spend next
year in Paris researching a
Marxist theory of urbanization,
and gathering source material
relating to 20th century urban
development. The Marxist theory
of urbanization, he explained,
examines both the dynamics of
capital accumulation and the
politics of the time; because it
spans both economic and
political disciplines, it provides a
more complete picture.
Marxist Theory
The sponsorship of
work
relating to Marxist theory was
hailed as a milestone by Harvey,
who stated, "Universities have
lived in the shadow of
McCarthyism and have never
gotten out of it because people
are still fearful of its [Marxist]
ramifications."

Harvey felt that Marxist
studies have been neglected at
Hopkins and called for the
establishment of a small group of
five or six members to pursue
this area. When questioned about
the interest shown by students
for such studies, he replied, "38
people showed up for my course
on Marx last semester so demand
seems apparent. Given the
resurgence of interest, it's
'surprising no one else teaches a
course relating to Marxist

philosophies."
Dr. Entwisle, in contrast to Dr.
Harvey, will be staying at
Hopkins to pursue research in the
sociology of human development
with Leslie Hayduk, a graduate
student. Entwisle said
that
data has been collected since
1969 on the development of an
'academic self-image" of
children in the first through third
grades; the aim of the project is
to analyze this data and
ultimately write a book on the

topic.
Simon Gugenheim once
Senator from Colorado and a
member of the family which
dominated the U.S. mining and
smelting industry in the first
third of this century, established
the fellowship in 1925, in
memory of his son, John Simon
Gugenheim, who died in 1922.
The foundation, originally
-designed to aid scholars and
artists, has given away over $65
million since its inception.

scholarships
The establishment of merit scholarships raises some
fundamental 'questions concerning the financial aid
philosophy of the university, as well as the motives for the
inception of such a program.
Without question, the mechanism should not extend to
those students already enrolled, for no adequate criteria exist
to determine the recipients. In -fact, the already competitive
atmosphere would be intensified. Moreover, it is common
knowledge that a student's intellectual ability cannot be
determined by standardized measurements of student
achievement, such as the sacrosanct GPA.
Perhaps these merit scholarships could be used to attract
capable prospective freshmen. However, the rationale behind
any merit scholarship is to attract students with exceptional
potential. To also assert that such awards might selectively
relieve the middle class financial strain, is unrealistic. Those
with private education, for example, would have a necessarily
unfair advantage.
The underlying concept for these merit scholarships would
be better serviced through the institution of a special h onors
program, whereby individuals could work in association with
faculty members. The implementation of such curricular
options would not only facilitate closer faculty-student
relations, but also attract the truly intellectually motivated.
The funds allotted for the merit scholarships should be
utilized to expand the current financial aid program on the
basis of financial need. Although Hopkins tuitions costs
compare favorably with peer insitutions, they still place a
considerable burden upon all students.
Students admitted to any honors curriculum should be
selected on the basis of potential demonstrated through
original research or a proposal for same, with mandatory
faculty interviews. Grades and CEEB tests should only be
considered marginally.
In light of the increased competition for promising
students among the finest educational institutions, it
becomes necessary for Hopkins to make use of all its elusive
power-. to maintain its high quality, or settle for a less than
optimal student body.

"Lowering Higher Education,"
Nicholas von
by Columnist
Hoffman, first appeared in .The
Washington Post, March 19,
1976.
It's getting less attention than
the Bicentennial but 1976 is also
the 100th birthday of the
modern American university.
Ceremonies commemorating the
occassion have recently been held
at The Johns Hopkins University,
a fitting place since The Hopkins
is thought by most historians of
education to be the first
recognizably modern university.
It bears the hallmarks. Prior to
its foundation, the primary
impetus for higher education
came from church groups. Not
surprisingly, since College was
regarded as a process of moral
formation as much as anything
else, but the Hopkins was started
by industrial capitalism, the
fruits of profit from the
Baltimore and Ohio railroad.
At the Hopkins, the older aim
of training up civilized Christian
gentlemen was dropped in favor
of a primary emphasis on
research. The Johns Hopkins
University was the first
institution to subordinate
student needs to research
demands by setting up the
departmental structure, now
universal in our higher education.
By doing away with the unitary
college by segmenting it into
specialized, departmental areas,
the undergraduate was converted
from. the status of traditional
student into what he today, a
potential recruit for a higher
degree. It was at the Hopkins
that the process of debasing the
B.A. into a useless kindergarten
certificate was begun.
in place of the B.A.,,the Ph.D.
was imported from Germany and
made the emblem of academic
distinction. A few doctorates had
been granted at Yale before the
Hopkins began awarding them
but it was at this new place of
learning in Baltimore that the
modern Ph.D. system was
erected.

The system of publishing
pedantic junk or perishing was
started at The Hopkins with the
founding of the first university
press and the appearance of The
American Journal of
Mathematics in 1877. In short
order, there were a skillion more
journals for the effluvia of the
professoriate. Within 25 years of
the founding of The Hopkins, the
Ph.D. system had already become
so pre tensious, wasteful and
inimical to real learning, that it
was being attacked in exactly the
same manner and for the same
reasons. Calling the new system
an "octopus," William James in
1903 said the degree was "a
sham, a bauble, a dodge whereby
to decorate the catalogues of
schools and colleges."
Aped
Harvard, where James taught,
nevertheless quickly aped The
Johns Hopkins system. But that
alone doesn't account for the
rapid spread of the Ph.D. and all
that it has brought with it in the
way of curriculum
standardization, grade-point
averages and the other
burdensome characteristics of
contemporary higher education.
The credit or the blame for
destroying the older education
with its emphasis on
individualism, humane studies
and moral purpose goes to
corporate capitalism, specifically
Andrew Carnegie and John D.
Rockefeller.
Both of them are up gigantic
educational charitable trusts
which dispensed money on the
condition that college and
universities change themselves to
fit a new national system of
interchangeable academic parts.
Carnegie, for example, demanded
that the chairman of every
department be a Ph.D. It's also
noteworthy that Carnegie nsisted
that religiously affiliated schools
cut their church ties as a
condition for receiving money.
Thus it is an occassion for
smirking when modern day
corporate givers complain about

the immorality of the
contemporary university. It
probably would have happened
anyway, but the impact of
Carnegie/Rockefeller is not only
a crystalline example of the
political power of tax-emempt
charitable money, it also shows
how closely higher education was
designed by and is run for the
needs of corporate capitalism.
In recent decades the costs
have grown so large that not even
the Rockefellers can pick up the
tab anymore, so the financial
responsibility has shifted over to
the government. What's worth
mentioning, though, is that the
system has remained absolutely
as it was 75 or 100 years ago.
hardlto think of any other
major institution that has been as
rigidly impervious to any change
The student complaints of the
last decade have had absolutely
no effect on the administration
and organization of the
university.
Nor have the budget cuts of
the '70's. No university has
seriously asked itself whether it

industry to budget cuts has been
to stigmatize people like Ronald

jack up the tuition while

product.
The waste, the sloth, the

education, is an open scandal and

costs in ignorance and money
and time are borne by the
students, their parents, and the
general public, all of whom are
cheated, and that's the way it's
going to stay while outfits like
the Russell Sage Foundation. the
20th Century Fund and the
Rockefeller Foundation finance
colloquia on new directions and
dimensions for education.

scholarships
The establishment of merit scholarships raises some
fundamental 'questions concerning the financial aid
philosophy of the university, as well as the motives for the
inception of such a program.
Without question, the mechanism should not extend to
those students already enrolled, for no adequate criteria exist
to determine the recipients. In -fact, the already competitive
atmosphere would be intensified. Moreover, it is common
knowledge that a student's intellectual ability cannot be
determined by standardized measurements of student
achievement, such as the sacrosanct GPA.
Perhaps these merit scholarships could be used to attract
capable prospective freshmen. However, the rationale behind
any merit scholarship is to attract students with exceptional
potential. To also assert that such awards might selectively
relieve the middle class financial strain, is unrealistic. Those
with private education, for example, would have a necessarily
unfair advantage.
The underlying concept for these merit scholarships would
be better serviced through the institution of a special h onors
program, whereby individuals could work in association with
faculty members. The implementation of such curricular
options would not only facilitate closer faculty-student
relations, but also attract the truly intellectually motivated.
The funds allotted for the merit scholarships should be
utilized to expand the current financial aid program on the
basis of financial need. Although Hopkins tuitions costs
compare favorably with peer insitutions, they still place a
considerable burden upon all students.
Students admitted to any honors curriculum should be
selected on the basis of potential demonstrated through
original research or a proposal for same, with mandatory
faculty interviews. Grades and CEEB tests should only be
considered marginally.
In light of the increased competition for promising
students among the finest educational institutions, it
becomes necessary for Hopkins to make use of all its elusive
power-. to maintain its high quality, or settle for a less than
optimal student body.

"Lowering Higher Education,"
Nicholas von
by Columnist
Hoffman, first appeared in .The
Washington Post, March 19,
1976.
It's getting less attention than
the Bicentennial but 1976 is also
the 100th birthday of the
modern American university.
Ceremonies commemorating the
occassion have recently been held
at The Johns Hopkins University,
a fitting place since The Hopkins
is thought by most historians of
education to be the first
recognizably modern university.
It bears the hallmarks. Prior to
its foundation, the primary
impetus for higher education
came from church groups. Not
surprisingly, since College was
regarded as a process of moral
formation as much as anything
else, but the Hopkins was started
by industrial capitalism, the
fruits of profit from the
Baltimore and Ohio railroad.
At the Hopkins, the older aim
of training up civilized Christian
gentlemen was dropped in favor
of a primary emphasis on
research. The Johns Hopkins
University was the first
institution to subordinate
student needs to research
demands by setting up the
departmental structure, now
universal in our higher education.
By doing away with the unitary
college by segmenting it into
specialized, departmental areas,
the undergraduate was converted
from. the status of traditional
student into what he today, a
potential recruit for a higher
degree. It was at the Hopkins
that the process of debasing the
B.A. into a useless kindergarten
certificate was begun.
in place of the B.A.,,the Ph.D.
was imported from Germany and
made the emblem of academic
distinction. A few doctorates had
been granted at Yale before the
Hopkins began awarding them
but it was at this new place of
learning in Baltimore that the
modern Ph.D. system was
erected.

The system of publishing
pedantic junk or perishing was
started at The Hopkins with the
founding of the first university
press and the appearance of The
American Journal of
Mathematics in 1877. In short
order, there were a skillion more
journals for the effluvia of the
professoriate. Within 25 years of
the founding of The Hopkins, the
Ph.D. system had already become
so pre tensious, wasteful and
inimical to real learning, that it
was being attacked in exactly the
same manner and for the same
reasons. Calling the new system
an "octopus," William James in
1903 said the degree was "a
sham, a bauble, a dodge whereby
to decorate the catalogues of
schools and colleges."
Aped
Harvard, where James taught,
nevertheless quickly aped The
Johns Hopkins system. But that
alone doesn't account for the
rapid spread of the Ph.D. and all
that it has brought with it in the
way of curriculum
standardization, grade-point
averages and the other
burdensome characteristics of
contemporary higher education.
The credit or the blame for
destroying the older education
with its emphasis on
individualism, humane studies
and moral purpose goes to
corporate capitalism, specifically
Andrew Carnegie and John D.
Rockefeller.
Both of them are up gigantic
educational charitable trusts
which dispensed money on the
condition that college and
universities change themselves to
fit a new national system of
interchangeable academic parts.
Carnegie, for example, demanded
that the chairman of every
department be a Ph.D. It's also
noteworthy that Carnegie nsisted
that religiously affiliated schools
cut their church ties as a
condition for receiving money.
Thus it is an occassion for
smirking when modern day
corporate givers complain about

the immorality of the
contemporary university. It
probably would have happened
anyway, but the impact of
Carnegie/Rockefeller is not only
a crystalline example of the
political power of tax-emempt
charitable money, it also shows
how closely higher education was
designed by and is run for the
needs of corporate capitalism.
In recent decades the costs
have grown so large that not even
the Rockefellers can pick up the
tab anymore, so the financial
responsibility has shifted over to
the government. What's worth
mentioning, though, is that the
system has remained absolutely
as it was 75 or 100 years ago.
hardlto think of any other
major institution that has been as
rigidly impervious to any change
The student complaints of the
last decade have had absolutely
no effect on the administration
and organization of the
university.
Nor have the budget cuts of
the '70's. No university has
seriously asked itself whether it
might be able to do the same jot
or a better one for less money by
reorganizing itself. The general
response of the higher education
industry to budget cuts has been
to stigmatize people like Ronald
Reagan, who propose them, as
reactionaries. Either that or they
jack up the tuition while
continuing to give their student
customers an increasingly shabby
product.
The waste, the sloth, the
sloppy laziness and the pointless
prodigality in American highei
education, is an open scandal and
has been for several decades. The
costs in ignorance and money
and time are borne by the
students, their parents, and the
general public, all of whom are
cheated, and that's the way it's
going to stay while outfits like
the Russell Sage Foundation. the
20th Century Fund and the
Rockefeller Foundation finance
colloquia on new directions and
dimensions for education.
